{{Year nav topic5|2007|art}} <!-- -- formerly (19Apr07) nav-box was: [[List of years in Art]] {{yearbox | in?=in art | cp=20th century | c=21st century | cf=22nd century | yp1=2001 | yp2=2002 | yp3=2003 | yp4=2004 | yp5=2005 | year=2006 | ya1=2007 | ya2=2008 | ya3=2009 | dp3=1970s | dp2=1980s | dp1=1990s | d=2000s | da=0 | dn1=2010s | dn2=2020s | dn3=2030s |}} --> The year '''2007 in art''' involved some significant events and new works.
==Events== * [[10 June]] – [[21 November]] – 52nd [[Venice Biennale]]. * [[18 October]] – In New York City, the [[Salander-O'Reilly Galleries]] is forced into closure on the evening of the opening of a major [[Caravaggio]] exhibition, amidst scandal and lawsuits. * [[22 October]] – In [[Amersfoort]] ([[Netherlands]]) a [[Armando (artist)#Fire at the Armando museum, 2007|fire at the Armando museum]] destroys 63 paintings from the permanent and loan collections.<ref>{{cite web|title=Armando Museum in Ruins After Fire|url=http://www.blouinartinfo.com/news/story/25906/armando-museum-in-ruins-after-fire/|publisher=Blouin Artinfo|date=2007-10-24|accessdate=2014-01-07}}</ref> * [[2 November]] – ''[[Nightwatching]]'', [[Peter Greenaway]]'s film about [[Rembrandt]], is released. It is the first film in Greenaway's series "Dutch Masters".<ref>{{cite journal|last=Morgan|first=Nesta|title=''Nightwatching''|journal=film&festivals|volume=2|issue=2|pages=5|publisher=Wallflower Press, Film Culture Ltd.|location=United Kingdom|issn=1755-5485}}</ref> * [[14 November]] – [[Sotheby's]] sells ''[[La Fuensanta]]'' by [[Julio Romero de Torres]] to a private collector.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sothebys.com/en/auctions/ecatalogue/2012/european-paintings/lot.79.html|title=Julio Romero de Torres|publisher=[[Sotheby's]]|accessdate=2015-08-16}}</ref> * [[20 December]] – The [[Pablo Picasso]] painting ''[[Portrait of Suzanne Bloch]]'', together with [[Candido Portinari]]'s ''[http://ritualcafe.files.wordpress.com/2007/07/lavrador-de-cafe.jpg O Lavrador de Café]'', is stolen from the [[São Paulo Museum of Art]]. It is recovered about three weeks later.
==Exhibitions== *[[14 June]]-[[16 September]] - [[National Portrait Gallery, London|National Portrait Gallery]], "BP Portrait Award 2007"<ref>[http://www.npg.org.uk/whatson/exhibitions/2007/bp-portrait-award-2007.php National Portrait Gallery website]. Accessed 26 February 2014</ref> *September-December - [[Garden in Transit]], a [[public art]] exhibit, is displayed on New York City [[Taxicabs of the United States#New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission|taxis]] between September 2007 and December 2007
==Awards== *[[Archibald Prize]] – [[John Beard (artist)|John Beard]], ''Portrait of [[Janet Laurence]]'' *[[Arts & Cultural Council for Greater Rochester]] Artist of the Year – [[Manuel Rivera-Ortiz]] *[[Caldecott Medal]] – [[David Wiesner]], ''[[Flotsam (book)|Flotsam]]'' *[[Turner Prize]] – [[Mark Wallinger]], ''[[State Britain]]'' *[[Venice Biennale]] – (June 10 - November 21) **Lion d'Or [[Golden Lion]] for Lifetime Achievement:[[Malick Sidibé]] (Mali) **Lion d'Or for Best Pavilion: [[Andreas Fogarasi]] (Hungary) *[[Wynne prize]] – [[Philip Wolfhagen]], ''Winter Nocturne IV''
==Works== {{See also|Category:2007 paintings|Category:2007 sculptures}}
* [[Ed Dwight]] – ''[[Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. (Dwight sculpture)|Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.]]'' (sculpture, Houston, Texas) * [[David Hockney]] – ''[[Bigger Trees Near Warter]]'' * [[Stephen Kettle]] – [[Alan Turing statue|''Alan Turing'' statue]] (a sculpture in slate), Bletchley Park, England * [[Ian Rank-Broadley]] – ''The Stretcher Bearers'' and ''The Gates'' bronzes at [[Armed Forces Memorial]], Staffordshire, England * [[Neo Rauch]] ** ''[[Hunter's Room]]'' ** ''[[Waiting for the Barbarians (painting)|Waiting for the Barbarians]]'' *[[Allison Saar]] - "Swing Low" - [[Harriet Tubman Memorial]] at Harriet Tubman Plaza in [[Harlem]], [[Manhattan]], New York City.<ref>http://home2.nyc.gov/html/dcla/html/panyc/saar.shtml</ref> * [[Doris Salcedo]] – ''[[Shibboleth (artwork)|Shibboleth]]'' (installation at [[Tate Modern]], London) * [[Luke Sullivan]] – ''[[:File:The Fourth Secret of Fatima.jpg|The Fourth Secret of Fatima]]'' (sculpture)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://reuters.viewdle.com/video?vid=C417-RELIGIOUSART-1188516406.mpg&pid=bebc09f3ec1a3d94d3664dcb25efebc7 |title=Bin Laden & Virgin Mary in Art Row |first=Stefanie |last=McIntyre |publisher=Reuters |date=August 2007 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.usatoday.com/ondeadline/2007/09/furor-over-artw.html |title=Furor over Burqa-clad Virgin Mary, Jesus morphing into Osama bin Laden |work=USA Today |date=September 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080507073916/http://blogs.usatoday.com/ondeadline/2007/09/furor-over-artw.html |archivedate=2008-05-07 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.news.com.au/heraldsun/story/0,21985,22333103-661,00.html|title=Fury on Virgin Mary's Burqa|first1=Elizabeth|last1=Fortescue|first2=Heath|last2=Aston|newspaper=Herald Sun|date=August 2007}}</ref>
==Deaths==
===January to March=== *[[8 January]] – [[Iwao Takamoto]], [[Japanese American]] [[animator]], television producer, and film director (b.[[1925 in art|1925]]). *[[20 January]] – [[Dan Christensen]], American abstract painter (b.[[1942 in art|1942]]). *[[4 February]] – [[Jules Olitski]], American abstract painter, printmaker, and sculptor (b.[[1922 in art|1922]]). *[[14 February]] – [[Emmett Williams]], American poet and [[Fluxus]] artist (b.[[1925 in art|1925]]). *[[22 February]] **[[Lothar-Günther Buchheim]], German author, painter, and art collector (b.[[1918 in art|1918]]). **[[Miriam Mone]], Northern Irish fashion designer (b.[[1965 in art|1965]]; ovarian cancer).<ref>[http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2007/0223/1172182811315.html Miriam Mone obituary in ''The Irish Times'']</ref> *[[2 March]] – [[Madi Phala]], South African artist (b.[[1955 in art|1955]]). *[[6 March]] – [[Jean Baudrillard]], French [[culture theory|cultural theorist]], sociologist, philosopher, political commentator, and photographer (b.[[1929 in art|1929]]). *[[16 March]] – [[Raymond Nasher]], American [[art collector]] (b.[[1921 in art|1921]]).
===April to June=== *[[7 April]] – [[Johnny Hart]], American [[cartoonist]] (b.[[1931 in art|1931]]). *[[8 April]] – [[Sol LeWitt]], American [[Conceptual art|conceptual]] and [[Minimalism|minimalist]] artist (b.[[1928 in art|1928]]). *[[10 April]] – [[Salvatore Scarpitta]], American sculptor (b.[[1919 in art|1919]]). *[[15 April]] – [[Brant Parker]], American [[cartoonist]] (b.[[1920 in art|1920]]). *[[17 April]] – [[Kitty Carlisle Hart]], American singer, actress and New York State Council on the Arts member (b.[[1910 in art|1910]]). *[[3 May]] – [[Warja Honegger-Lavater]], [[Switzerland|Swiss]] artist and [[illustrator]] (b.[[1913 in art|1913]]). *[[26 May]] – [[James Beck (art historian)|James Beck]], American [[art history|art historian]] (b.[[1930 in art|1930]]). *[[28 May]] – [[Jörg Immendorff]], German painter, sculptor, stage designer and art professor (b.[[1945 in art|1945]]; [[Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis|ALS]]).<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/obituaries/story/0,,2101396,00.html Obituary], ''[[The Guardian]]'', 13 June 2007</ref> *[[2 June]] – [[Jerry Wilkerson]], American painter (b.[[1943 in art|1943]]). *[[17 June]] – [[Gianfranco Ferré]], Italian fashion designer (b.[[1944 in art|1944]]). *[[22 June]] – [[Bernd and Hilla Becher|Bernd Becher]], German photographer (b.[[1931 in art|1931]]). *[[26 June]] – [[Liz Claiborne (fashion designer)|Liz Claiborne]], Belgian-born American fashion designer and entrepreneur (b.[[1929 in art|1929]]).
===July to September=== *[[7 July]] – [[John Szarkowski]], American photographer, [[curator]], historian and critic (b.[[1925 in art|1925]]). *[[17 July]] – [[Jeremy Blake]], American [[digital artist]] and painter (b.[[1971 in art|1971]]). *[[22 July]] – [[Aleksandr Tatarskiy]], Russian animator, artist and film director (b.[[1950 in art|1950]]). *[[9 August]] – [[Joe O'Donnell (photojournalist)|Joe O'Donnell]], American photographer (b.[[1922 in art|1922]]). *[[11 August]] – [[Maurice Boitel]], French painter (b.[[1919 in art|1919]]). *[[12 August]] **[[Elizabeth Murray (artist)|Elizabeth Murray]], American painter, printmaker and draughtsman (b.[[1940 in art|1940]]). **[[Mike Wieringo]], American [[comic book]] artist (b.[[1963 in art|1963]]). *[[17 August]] – [[Edward Avedisian]], American abstract painter (b.[[1936 in art|1936]]). *[[24 September]] – [[Lenore Tawney]], American [[fiber art]]ist (b.[[1907 in art|1907]]). *[[25 September]] – [[André Emmerich]], American gallerist.
===October to December=== *[[5 October]] – [[Alexandra Boulat]], French photographer (b.[[1962 in art|1962]]). *[[8 October]] – [[Constantine Andreou]], Greek painter and sculptor (b.[[1917 in art|1917]]). *[[21 October]] **[[R. B. Kitaj]], American-born English artist (b.[[1932 in art|1932]]). **[[Ileana Sonnabend]], art dealer and gallerist. *[[30 October]] – [[Norbert Lynton]], British art historian and Professor of the History of Art (b.[[1927 in art|1927]]). *[[16 November]] – [[Paul Brach]], American [[Abstract art|abstract]] painter, [[lecturer]] and educator (b.[[1924 in art|1924]]). *[[4 December]] **[[Norval Morrisseau]], [[Aboriginal peoples in Canada|Aboriginal Canadian]] artist (b.[[1932 in art|1932]]). **[[Herman Rose]] 98, painter (b.[[1909 in art|1909]]). *[[7 December]] - [[Noel Forster]], British painter (b.[[1932 in art|1932]]) *[[14 December]] – [[Ismail Gulgee]], Pakistani painter (b.[[1926 in art|1926]]). *[[31 December]] – [[Michael Goldberg (painter)|Michael Goldberg]], American [[abstract expressionism|abstract expressionist]] painter and teacher (b.[[1924 in art|1924]]).

'''Anchor Graphics''' is a non-profit fine art printshop and gallery in [[Chicago, Illinois]] that is part of the Art + Design Department at [[Columbia College Chicago]]. It was founded in 1990 by David Jones and Marilyn Propp.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1996-06-07/entertainment/9606070202_1_drawings-etching-prints|title=Anchor Shows Printmaking Process As Well As Product|publisher=Chicago Tribune|first=Barbara B. |last=Buchholz|date=7 June 1996}}</ref> It is known for the quality of its prints as well as its educational programming.<ref>Second Sight: Printmaking in Chicago 1935-1995," by James Yood. Essays by Mark Pascale, James Yood, and David Mickenberg (Mary and Leigh Block Gallery, Northwestern University, 1996), p. 50 and 51.</ref><ref name=demo3>{{cite journal |url=http://issuu.com/columbiacollegepubs/docs/demo3|first=Anne|last=Wiens|title=The Fine Print|journal=Demo3|publisher=Columbia College|date=2006}}</ref>
==Programs== For twenty years, Anchor provided free classes for high school students, and had an outreach program called Press on Wheels (POW) which brought [[printmaking]] into schools, galleries, museums, and community centers.<ref name=demo3 /> Workshops were open to students of all ages who learned to create handmade prints. During the Toulouse-Lautrec and Rembrandt exhibitions at the [[Art Institute of Chicago]], a press was brought to the museum, and Anchor staff demonstrated the print processes and tools used by both artists. Ann Weins writes in DEMO 3, pages 24–28: "Anchor Graphics maintains an impressive schedule of classes, workshops, residencies, and lectures, all the while publishing exquisite, hand-pulled prints."<ref name=demo3 />
The Artist-in-Residence Program was created to provide uninterrupted use of the shop by national and international printmakers for research and the development of new work. Scraping the Surface,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.colum.edu/academics/anchor-graphics/Education/Lecture_Series/Past_Lectures/McCay_Lecture.html|title=Winsor McCay|work=colum.edu}}</ref> a free lecture series open to the public, presented talks by artists, curators, museum specialists, conservators, collectors, and others with an interest in prints,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.colum.edu/academics/anchor-graphics/Information/history.html|title=History|work=colum.edu}}</ref> and was funded by the Terra Foundation for American Art from 2006 - 2010.<ref>http://www.terraamericanart.org/grant/anchor-graphics-columbia-college/</ref>
Located in [[Ukrainian Village, Chicago|Ukrainian Village]], and then Chicago's [[Ukrainian Village, Chicago|River North]], Anchor moved to the [[Chicago Loop|South Loop]] upon becoming a part of the Art + Design Department at [[Columbia College Chicago]] in 2006. According to [[David Mickenberg]], former director of the David Museum and Cultural Center, and of the [[Mary and Leigh Block Museum of Art|Block Museum]] at [[Northwestern University]], " [Anchor's reputation] has to do with. . . the balancing act between education and collaborative printmaking. . . "<ref name=jones>{{cite news|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2006-06-25/news/0606240244_1_contemporary-artists-prints-david-jones|title=Dropping Anchor at Columbia|publisher=Chicago Tribune|first=Jeff |last=Huebner|date=25 June 2006}}</ref> Anchor provides Artist-in-Residencies, open studio time for the Chicago community, adult classes, and publishing and contract work.
Master Printers David Jones and Chris Flynn have published editions by artists such as the late [[Ed Paschke]], the late [[Ellen Lanyon]], [[Jim Nutt]], [[Kay Rosen]], [[Karl Wirsum]], [[Phyllis Bramson]], [[Eleanor Spiess-Ferris]] [[Kerry James Marshall]], Rachel Niffenegger, [[Saya Woolfalk|Saya Woolfolk]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sayawoolfalk.com/webarticles/Anchor.htm |title=Anchor Graphics |work=sayawoolfalk.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304102434/http://www.sayawoolfalk.com/webarticles/Anchor.htm |archivedate=2016-03-04 }}</ref> and others.<ref name=jones /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.colum.edu/academics/anchor-graphics/Publishing_Projects/index.html|title=Publishing Projects|work=colum.edu}}</ref>
==Funding== Anchor Graphics is funded from private donations and from the [[Illinois Arts Council]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.arts.illinois.gov/news/iaca-announces-first-round-fy2015-grants|title=IACA Announces First Round of 2015 Grants|publisher=Illinois Arts Council}}</ref> Previous funders include the MacArthur Foundation Fund for Arts and Culture <ref>https://www.macfound.org/press/press-releases/sixty-five-grants-totaling-115-million-are-made-to-chicago-area-small-and-mid-size-arts-and-cultural-organizations-through-macarthur-funds-at-the-prince-and-driehaus-foundations-december-12-2003/</ref>

[[File:Vergèce.jpg|thumb|right|Title page of the ''[[Hexameron]]'', copied by Vergecio]] '''Angelo Vergecio''' ({{lang-el|Άγγελος Βεργέκιος}}, {{lang-fr|Ange Vergèce}}; 1505–1569) was a [[Greeks|Greek]] copyist from [[Crete]] active in [[Venice]] and [[France]]. He became a royal scribe for [[Francis I of France]] and his successors, was responsible for copying over fifty Greek manuscripts, and played a role in the dissemination of Greek among the humanist circles in France. His handwriting formed the basis of the ''[[grecs du roi]]'' typeface designed by [[Claude Garamond]].

''Nommer le monde : origine des noms de fleuves, de montagnes et de ce qui s'y trouve''. Villeneuve-d'Ascq : Presses universitaires du Septentrion, 2011. * Ernst Gamillscheg, Dieter Harlfinger and Herbert Hunger (dir.) ''Repertorium der griechischen Kopisten 800-1600'', Veröffentlichungen der Kommission für Byzantinistik 3-1, Vienna : Österreichische Akademie der Wissenschaften, 1981. * Philip Hofer et G. W. [https://books.google.com/books?id=qwIoAAAAYAAJ&pg=PR175 « Ange Vergèce », ''Bibliographie hellénique''. Paris : 1885. t. I, pp. cxxv-cxxxvi]. * Pierre de Nolhac. ''Ronsard et l'humanisme''. Paris : Champion, 1921, p. 39. * Henri Omont. ''[http://bibnum-stendhal.upmf-grenoble.fr/items/show/59 Catalogues des manuscrits grecs de Fontainebleau sous François Ier et Henri II]''. Paris : Imprimerie nationale, 1889. 4°, XXXIX-466 p. * Henri Omont. « Procès d’Ange Vergèce au Châtelet et au Parlement de Paris (1561) », ''Bibliothèque de l’École des Chartes'' 77 (1916) pp. 516-520. * Glenn Peers, « Forging Byzantine animals : Manuel Philes in Renaissance France », ''Rivista di studi bizantini e neoellenici'' 49 (2012), pp. 79-103. * Glenn Peers. « Thinking with Animals: Byzantine natural history in sixteenth-century France », ''Bibliothèque d’Humanisme et Renaissance'' 68 (2006), pp. 457–484. * Glenn Peers. « A Cretan in Paris : Angelos Vergekios and Greek natural history in the French Renaissance », ''Pepragmena Th’ Diethnous Kretologikou Synedriou. Elounta, 1-6 Oktovriou 2001. Tomos B2: Architetektonike, Istoria tes Technes, Nomismatike, Topographia kai Topiographia, Diepistemonikes Symvoles'', Herakleion, 2004 (2006), {{p.|419-440}}.

{{EngvarB|date=June 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} [[File:Art Apart Logo.jpg|thumb|right|Art Apart Fair logo]] '''Art Apart Fair''' is Singapore's first<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://dev.stcommunities.sg/entertainment/show/st-review/more-art-fairs-are-being-launched |title=More art fairs are being launched |date=11 January 2014 |website=The Straits Times |last=Shetty |first=Deepika |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150216095717/http://dev.stcommunities.sg/entertainment/show/st-review/more-art-fairs-are-being-launched |archivedate=16 February 2015 }}</ref> hotel-based boutique art fair. Initially called Worlds Apart Fair in January 2013, the success of the fair encouraged a second edition, later renamed as Art Apart Fair as part of a series of "Apart Fairs".<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url = http://sea.blouinartinfo.com/news/story/920838/art-apart-hotel-fair-returns-at-parkroyal-on-pickering|title = Art Apart hotel fair returns at Parkroyal on Pickering|date = 25 June 2013|website = Blouin Art Info|publisher = Blouin Art Info Southeast Asia}}</ref>
Art Apart coincides with Singapore Art Week, an initiative launched by the [[National Arts Council (Singapore)|National Arts Council]], along with the [[Singapore Tourism Board]] and [[Economic Development Board|Singapore Economic Development Board]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nac.gov.sg/art-forms/visual-arts/festivals-events/singapore-art-week-2015 |title=Singapore Art Week 2015 |website=National Arts Council |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150213033328/http://www.nac.gov.sg/art-forms/visual-arts/festivals-events/singapore-art-week-2015 |archivedate=13 February 2015 }}</ref>
The fairs take place twice biannually – during January and July – in Singapore. Art Apart made its international debut in London in October 2014<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://artapartfair.com/london/about-art-apart-fair/|title = About Art Apart Fair|website = Art Apart Fair London}}</ref> at the Town Hall Hotel. It will be setting its stage in New York in October 2016.
Art Apart Fair serves as a platform to provide support towards emerging artists with the potential to become established. The fair gives artists the opportunity to showcase their works<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://artapartfair.com/about-art-apart-fair/|title = About Art Apart Fair|website = Art Apart Fair}}</ref> and gain recognition among art lovers and collectors.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url = http://www.ssphere.com/news/latest-blogs/entry/art-apart-fair-2013-presents-a-canvas-for-the-next-wave-of-asian-artists-to-the-rest-of-the-world.html|title = Art Apart Fair 2013 presents a canvas for the next wave of Asian artists to the rest of the world|date = 15 June 2013|website = SSphere Online|last = Tan|first = Billy}}</ref> In January 2014, some 33 galleries and 1,500 artists' work from countries such as Taiwan, China, Australia, Kazakhstan, Croatia, Japan, Vietnam, Austria, Cambodia, South Korea, Russia, Spain and Germany, were featured.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.todayonline.com/entertainment/arts/art-apart-fair-go-international|title = Art Apart Fair to go international|date = 8 January 2014|website = TODAY Online|last = Aljaru|first = Mysara Bte Mohamad}}</ref>
Some of the galleries that have exhibited with Art Apart are South Korea's [[Seoul Arts Centre]], Shanghai's Nancy Gallery, Madrid's Jorge & Fernando Alcolea Gallery<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.herworldplus.com/lifestyle/stuff-do/art-apart-fair-2013 |title=Art Apart Fair 2013 |website=Her World Plus |publisher=Singapore Press Holdings |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924025955/http://www.herworldplus.com/lifestyle/stuff-do/art-apart-fair-2013 |archivedate=24 September 2015 }}</ref> and Russia's Gallery 11.12.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.expatliving.sg/Things_to_do/whats_on_calendar/art-and-culture/Art-Fair-Art-Apart-Fair-2015-76210.ece|title = Art Apart Fair 2015|website = Expat Living}}</ref>
In comparison to other art fairs, Art Apart focuses on selecting galleries with emerging artists with a possibility of becoming established in their national or international market.
Due to the high costs of exhibiting at art fairs and the presence of many artists struggling to succeed financially,<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://artapartfair.com/london/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/pressrelfinallogo.pdf|title = Art Apart Fair – Singapore returns for its fourth edition|date = 8 May 2014|website = Art Apart Fair}}</ref> there is an "Adopt An Artist" initiative, where a Patron of the Arts<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://artapartfair.com/patrons/|title = Patron of the Arts|website = Art Apart Fair}}</ref> and sponsors help to fund these artists. Galleries that are invited to showcase new works at Art Apart also help support the emerging artists by paying for the exhibiting fee. Works have to be new and not shown at other art fairs before.
Besides providing support for emerging artists, part of the revenue generated from the sales of art works and tickets goes towards helping the young and elderly in Singapore. One of the beneficiaries includes [[Halogen Foundation (Singapore)|Halogen Foundation]],<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://main.artapartfair.com/assets/uploads/files/aaf_jan_catalogue.pdf |title=Art Apart Fair 3rd Edition Catalogue |website=Art Apart Fair |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150216102258/http://main.artapartfair.com/assets/uploads/files/aaf_jan_catalogue.pdf |archivedate=16 February 2015 }}</ref> an educational charity that helps to develop young leaders and entrepreneurs.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.halogen.sg/home/about-us/|title = About Us|publisher = Halogen Foundation}}</ref> Another beneficiary is the Lions Befrienders Service Association,<ref name=":0" /> Singapore's largest direct service voluntary welfare organisation, that assists the elderly and helps them engage with the community.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lionsbefrienders.org.sg/aboutlbsa_ourhistory.html |title=Our History |website=Lions Befrienders |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150216103049/http://www.lionsbefrienders.org.sg/aboutlbsa_ourhistory.html |archivedate=16 February 2015 }}</ref>
== History == The idea of holding an art fair in a hotel first originated in 1994 as the [[The Armory Show (art fair)|Gramercy International Art Fair]] in the rooms of [[Gramercy Park Hotel]] in New York City. The fair was highly successful, and it is now renamed "[[The Armory Show (art fair)|The Armory Show]]".
The concept of a hotel-based art fair breaks the conventional presentation of art in a whitewashed gallery space.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url = http://sg.asia-city.com/events/news/art-apart-fair-2014-brings-art-hotel-third-time-jan-17-19|title = Art Apart Fair is set to take place at PARKROYAL hotel this month|date = 14 January 2014|website = The Insider's Guide to Singapore}}</ref> Visitors are provided with a good idea of how these works would look like in a home setting, as they are being displayed in a more informal setting, such as on beds, table tops, chairs and even bathrooms.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.artitute.com/2013/01/24/a-new-art-fair-worlds-apart-singapore/|title = A new art fair – Worlds Apart Singapore|date = 24 January 2013|website = Artitute|last = Anthony|first = Nicola}}</ref>
Inspired by this layout, Art Apart founder and director Rosalind Lim decided to bring the idea over to Singapore. With over 38 years of experience in diverse fields, such as Public Relations, Branding, Marketing and Event Management, she built the foundation for the first successful hotel art fair – the Worlds Apart Fair in January 2013<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://artapartfair.com/about-the-organizer/|title = About the Organizer|website = Art Apart Fair}}</ref> at [[Conrad Centennial Singapore]]. The fair was later renamed Art Apart Fair<ref name=":1"/> and moved to [[Parkroyal|Parkroyal on Pickering]], where the entire 14th floor – rooms, lobbies and corridors – is converted into art galleries.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url = http://artapartfair.com/welcome/|title = Welcome|website = Art Apart Fair}}</ref>
== Singapore Editions ==
=== Worlds Apart Fair (First Edition) === The inaugural edition of Worlds Apart Fair was held from 25 to 27 January 2013 in 40 rooms at [[Conrad Centennial Singapore]], and saw more than 3,000 visitors and buyers.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.mynewsdesk.com/sg/luxy-international/pressreleases/art-apart-fair-2014-its-worlds-apart-942925|title = Art Apart Fair 2014 'Its Worlds Apart'|date = 27 December 2013|website = My News Desk}}</ref> The fair showcased some 3,400 art works, ranging from paintings and photography to video art, sculptures and installations.<ref name=":4"/>
Worlds Apart Fair featured emerging contemporary artists from Asia, Africa, Lebanon, Europe, the Americas and Australia, with a greater focus on rising artists from Singapore.<ref name=":4"/> Some of the galleries that exhibited in clude [[Vertical Submarine]] (Singapore), Villa Del Arte Galleries (Spain) and Art Bridge Contemporary (Korea).
Two Chinese talents, Singaporean actor [[Qi Yuwu]] and renowned Chinese artist [[Feng Zhengjie]] collaborated for the first time specially for this fair and presented their work 'Showcase on Print'.
=== Art Apart Fair (Second Edition) === Worlds Apart was renamed as Art Apart as part of a series of "Apart Fairs".
The second edition of Art Apart was held from 5 to 7 July 2013 at [[Parkroyal|Parkroyal on Pickering]], and featured over 120 Asian artists and galleries. The art works were focused on Korea and revolved around themes such as "Korean Wave", "Asian Spirit" and "Butterfly Effect".<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://comesingapore.com/events/view/21924/art-apart-fair-2013|title = Art Apart Fair 2013|website = Come Singapore}}</ref>
In addition to the display of artworks, the fair included talks by prominent artists and industry experts from around Asia.<ref name=":2"/>
About 3,000 visitors attended Art Apart Fair 2nd Edition.
=== Art Apart Fair (Third Edition) === The third edition of Art Apart took place from 17 to 19 January 2014, showcased more than 1,500 art pieces<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://blogs.wsj.com/scene/2014/01/17/beyond-art-stage-singapore/|title = Beyond Art Stage Singapore|date = 17 January 2014|website = Scene Asia|last = Ang|first = Kristiano}}</ref> from 12 countries, including Germany, South Korea, Russia and the Philippines.<ref name=":3"/>
Besides housing exhibitions such as "The Destruction of the Readymade Everyday", the main theme for Art Apart 3rd Edition was "The Artists' Garden" – a selection of 100 art pieces from the 33 participating galleries.<ref name=":6">{{Cite web|url = http://www.blouinartinfo.com/news/story/1000666/singapore-connection-brings-new-hotel-art-fair-to-london|title = Singapore 'connection' brings new hotel art fair to London|date = 12 January 2014|website = Blouin Art Info|publisher =Blouin Art Info International |last = Kolesnikov-Jessop|first = Sonia}}</ref>
Over 4,000 people visited the art fair, an increase from the 2nd Edition.
=== Art Apart Fair (Fourth Edition) === The fourth edition of Art Apart was held from 18 to 20 July 2014, where more than 2,000 art pieces were exhibited, with a focus on works by Russian artists. The aim of the event was to introduce Eastern European Art, such as works from Moscow, Kazakhstan, Croatia and Slovenia.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://artapartfair.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/Fireflyz.pdf|title = Worlds Apart|last = Chew|first = Esther|work = Fireflyz|access-date = }}</ref>
Apart from the display of art pieces, there were live paintings of portraits, talks by Russian art experts and Russian Art Performance.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://sagg.info/event/art-apart-fair-singapore-4th-edition/ |title=Art Apart Fair Singapore – 4th Edition |website=Singapore Art Gallery Guide |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402112012/http://sagg.info/event/art-apart-fair-singapore-4th-edition/ |archivedate=2 April 2015 }}</ref>
Similar to the previous edition, over 4,000 visitors visited Art Apart 4th Edition.
=== Art Apart Fair (Fifth Edition) === The fifth edition of Art Apart was held from 23 to 25 January 2015 at [[Parkroyal|Parkroyal on Pickering]]. Unlike past editions where the curations were focused on specific countries, such as Singapore, Korea and Russia, this edition showcased [[contemporary art]], highlighted conceptual art works and urban art works by street artists from all around the world. Some of the featured artists include emerging Russian artists [[Rinat Voligamsi]] and [[Maxim Bashev]], German artist Kaja el Attar and French artist Bruno Tanquerel.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://sg.asia-city.com/events/singapore-art/art-apart-5th-edition?page=2|title = Art Apart 5th Edition|website = The Insider's Guide to Singapore}}</ref>
Eight galleries from the previous editions of Art Apart made a return, such as Utterly Art, Gaze Gallery and [[Seoul Arts Centre]].<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://sagg.info/event/art-apart-fair-2015/|title = Art Apart Fair 2015|website = Singapore Art Gallery Guide}}</ref>
Over 4,000 visitors attended the fifth edition of the art fair.
=== Art Apart Fair (Sixth Edition) ===
The sixth edition of Art Apart was held from 17 to 19 July 2015. Art Apart Fair featured artworks from the Philippines. The finest Filipino galleries including Big and Small, Gallery Qube, Art Quartel and more showcased the best of contemporary Filipino artworks. Leading the pack of Filipino artists was glass artist Ramon Orlina, who showcased pieces from his stellar three decades in the industry. The art works of Ronald Ventura, the auctions record-holder for Southeast Asian paintings, as well as Geraldine Javier, Marina Cruz, Randy Salon and more were present at the sixth edition.
=== Art Apart Fair (Seventh Edition) === The seventh edition of Art Apart will be held from 22 to 24 January 2016. Art Apart Fair will see the participation of more than 40 Singaporean artists alongside others hailing from Malaysia, Thailand, Korea, Iceland, America, Philippines, Russia and France. The Fair is possibly the largest ensemble of fresh, emerging Singaporean artists in an art fair and signals a shift in focus from previous editions that focused on a matrix of foreign artists and art genre. The Presidential Suite will be themed "Mosaic" and feature never-before-seen works of Benny Ong, Daniela Beltrani's curated selection of 12 Singapore-based artworks and Rosalind Lim's selection of designers-turned-artists, Hayden Ng and luxury shoe designer Mashizan Masjum. Author Bryan Koh will also be presenting his books at the Fair.
== Overseas Editions == Unlike the Singapore Editions, where the fairs are conducted biannually, the fairs held overseas – more specifically London and New York – will take place biennially.<ref name=":6"/>
=== Art Apart London (First Edition) === Art Apart made its international debut from 17 to 19 October 2014 at the Town Hall Hotel, in [[Bethnal Green]], East London. The show is believed to be the first hotel art fair that took place in London in a larger scale.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.londonlive.co.uk/news/2014-10-17/the-art-apart-fair|title = Book a room, browse the art – The Art Apart Fair|date = 17 October 2014|website = London Live}}</ref> The fair showcased over 2,000 contemporary works from more than 100 rising and mid-career artists, including artists such as Oscar Lett, Russell Marshall and Nikolai Ishchuk,<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://artapartfair.com/london/artists/|title = Art Apart Fair 2014, Artists }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://madeinshoreditch.co.uk/events/the-art-apart-fair/|title = The Art Apart Fair|website = Made in Shoreditch}}</ref> occupying the entire second floor of the hotel. Besides featuring artists, art pieces by silversmiths, jewellers and makers, such as Hans Stofer and David Clarke were exhibited as well. Over 3,000 visitors were expected to be present for the Art Apart London 1st Edition.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.russianartandculture.com/event-art-apart-art-fair-2014-the-town-hall-hotel-london-17-19-october/|title = Art Apart Fair 2014, The Town Hall Hotel, London, 17 – 19 October 2014|date = 11 July 2014|website = Russian Art and Culture}}</ref>
=== Art Apart New York (First Edition) === Art Apart is expected to debut in New York in March 2016.
=== Art Apart London (Second Edition) === The second edition of Art Apart in London is expected to be held in October 2016.

{{Infobox economist | name = Athanasios Asimakopulos | school_tradition = [[Post-Keynesian economics]] | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = 28 May 1930 | birth_place = [[Montreal|Montreal, Quebec]], Canada | death_date = {{Death date and age|1990|05|25|1930|05|28}} | death_place = Montreal, Quebec, Canada | nationality = [[Canadians|Canadian]] | institution = [[McGill University]] | field = [[Macroeconomics]] | alma_mater = [[University of Cambridge]] | influences = [[John Maynard Keynes]]
[[Roy Harrod]]
[[Joan Robinson]]
[[Michał Kalecki]] | influenced = | contributions = | awards = | signature = | repec_prefix = | repec_id = }} '''Athanasios "Tom" Asimakopulos''' ({{Lang-gr|Αθανάσιος Ασημακόπουλος}}) (May 28, 1930 – May 25, 1990) was a [[Canadians|Canadian]] [[economist]], who was the "William Dow Professor of Political Economy" in the Department of Economics, [[McGill University]], [[Montreal|Montreal, Quebec]], Canada.{{cite journal|last1=Harcourt|first1=G.C.|title=Athanasios (Tom) Asimakopulos, 1930-1990: A Memoir|journal=Journal of Post Keynesian Economics|date=1991|volume=14|issue=1|pages=39–48|jstor=4538271}} His monograph, ''Keynes's General Theory and Accumulation'', reviews important areas of [[John Maynard Keynes|Keynes's]] ''[[The General Theory of Employment, Interest and Money|General Theory]]'' and the theories of [[Capital accumulation|accumulation]] of two of his most distinguished followers, [[Roy Harrod]] and [[Joan Robinson]].Asimakopulos, Athanasios. [https://books.google.com/books?id=iCUGZire18IC&dq=athanasios+asimakopulos&printsec=frontcover&source=web&ots=yB8UZH-zNv&sig=QSoDXbobReK-r8MSqPXFsOQ6QDM#PPP1,M1 ''Keynes's General Theory and Accumulation''] (Modern Cambridge Economics Series) (Print on Demand). Cambridge University Press, 2004. {{ISBN|0-521-36815-4}} ==Biography== Asimakopulos was born in Montreal in 1930. He was educated at [[McGill University]] earning a B.A. in 1951 and an M.A. in 1953. In September 1953 Tom went to [[University of Cambridge|Cambridge]]; his research topic was a three-commodity, three-country study in international trade theory entitled ''Productivity Changes, the Trade Balance and the Terms of Trade''.Asimakopulos, A. [https://www.jstor.org/stable/2661902 ''A Note on Productivity Changes and the Terms of Trade'']. Oxford Economic Papers, New Series, Vol. 9, No. 2 (Jun., 1957), pp. 225–233. With his classmate [[Keith Frearson]], the Australian economist, Tom went to [[Joan Robinson|Joan Robinson's]] lectures on what would become ''The Accumulation of Capital''Robinson, Joan. [https://www.questia.com/library/book/the-accumulation-of-capital-by-joan-robinson.jsp ''The Accumulation of Capital'']. London: Macmillan Company, 1965. First published 1956. – Robinson's ''magnum opus'', which sought to extend [[Keynesian economics|Keynes's theory]] to account for long-run issues of growth and [[capital accumulation]]. Initially Asimakopulos was irritated by Robinson's criticisms of the orthodox theories of value and distribution and [[Neoclassical economics|neoclassical methodology]] on which he had been brought up. Asimakopulos also went regularly to research students's seminars run by [[Piero Sraffa]], [[Robin Marris]], and [[Nicholas Kaldor]]. Asimakopulos was a Lecturer in Economics and Political Science from 1956 to 1957 at McGill. From 1957 to 1959 he worked as an Assistant Professor at the Royal Military College. In 1959 he returned to McGill and became an assistant professor, working close to [[J.C. Weldon]]. Promoted to the position of associate professor in 1963, he became a full professor in 1966. In 1988 he was appointed ''"William Dow Professor of Political Economy"'' on Weldon's vacancy. He served as Chairman of the Department of Economics from 1974 to 1978. Teaching was his top priority; Asimakopulos loved teaching the microeconomics course to the Honours Students at McGill. Even though he had an assistant, Asimakopulos made sure that, from time to time, he gave tutorials himself, on which he would emphasize, ''ad nauseam'' the importance of the ''assumptions'' of the analysis and its implications on the results of the theoretical model studied. He wrote extensively on the work of such economic theorists as J. M. Keynes, Joan Robinson, and [[Michał Kalecki]]. He was active in many professional associations and organizations. He held numerous fellowships and was a Visiting Professor and a Fellow at universities in the United States, England and Australia. From 1976 to 1990 he was a Fellow of the Royal Society of Canada. Athanasios Asimakopulos died of leukemia in 1990. ==Contributions to economic theory== Asimakopulos was a [[Post Keynesian]] / "[[Michał Kalecki|Kaleckian]]" scholar, who elaborated upon Michał Kalecki's theories.Lavoie, Marc. [http://cje.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/content/abstract/19/6/789 ''The Kaleckian model of growth and distribution and its neo-Ricardian and neo-Marxian critiques'']. Cambridge Journal of Economics 19 (6), 1993, pp. 789–81. Asimakopulos wrote mainly around and on Keynesian themes and on growth, distribution and technical progress (the latter often with Weldon). Over time Kalecki's contributions came to be a major influence and interest; Tom came back to Kalecki, influenced by Joan Robinson. Kalecki stresses on determinants of income distribution, determinants of economic activity, determinants of profits, long-run growth, prospects of economy, or impact of imperfect competition on growth of income has been an important inspiration to many economists we call [[Post Keynesian]]s, including Asimakopulos.Nuti, D. M. [http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1132/is_n5_v39/ai_6123769 ''Michal Kalecki – excerpts from a paper entitled Michal Kalecki's Contributions to the Theory and Practice of Socialist Planning'']. Monthly Review, Oct. 1987.[http://cepa.newschool.edu/het/schools/postk.htm The American Post Keynesians] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090418155213/http://cepa.newschool.edu/het/schools/postk.htm |date=April 18, 2009 }} An advantage of theories that originate from Kalecki is that they are closer to what can be called "normal" theories. Kalecki's papers are acceptably formalized and not as extensively open to various interpretations as Keynes' ''General Theory''.Lavoie. Marc. [http://rrp.sagepub.com/cgi/content/abstract/28/4/113 ''Traverse, Hysteresis, and Normal Rates of Capacity Utilization in Kaleckian Models of Growth and Distribution'']. Review of Radical Political Economics 28 (4), 1996, 113–147. When [[Post Keynesians]] treat production side of the economy in their models, they usually inhabit their models with firms, which operate within neither perfectly competitive environment, nor within perfect monopoly setting. Post Keynesian firms usually set their prices as mark-ups above their prime costs. Profits of those firms usually, along with ''"animal spirits and expectations"'', have pronounced impact on investment decisions and therefore determine profits in the future. This double-sided relationship between profits and investment is clearly in spirit of Asimakopulos (1971)[https://www.jstor.org/journals/00084239.html Asimakopulos, Athanasios. ''The Determination of Investment in Keynes's Model'', Canadian JE, 1971, vol. 4, issue 3, pp. 382–88.] The most succinct definition of post-Keynesian economics comes from Joan Robinson: ::To me, the expression '''''post-Keynesian''''' has a definite meaning; it applies to an economic theory or method of analysis which takes account of the difference between the future and the past. {{small|(emphasis in the original)}} {{small|(1978; CEP, vol. V, 1979b, 210)}} ===Post Keynesianism=== The principal concern of [[Post Keynesians]] is to have a more complex and realistic aggregate [[supply and demand]] framework that includes mark-up pricing, the trend to monopoly, the workings of [[endogenous money]] and credit, circular and cumulative causation, and a pragmatic guide to policy. The workings of uncertainty lead to an unstable capitalistic system that requires the making of agreements and accords to promote stability. At the global level, it requires a fairer distribution of power such that the onus is on nations with trade surpluses to adjust their policies. More than anything, Post Keynesians eschew the quantity theory of money, since money and credit are seen to affect output and employment in both the short and long term. Indeed, like the institutionalists and Marxists, they see the capitalist economy as a monetary system of production, where money and [[creative financing]] are essential aspects of its functioning.[http://hetsa.fec.anu.edu.au/review/ejournal/pdf/37-RA-2.pdf O'Hara, Phillip Anthony. ''The Revival of Political Economy and its Main Protagonists: 1960s to the Present''. History of Economics Review pp. 140–151] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090617024347/http://hetsa.fec.anu.edu.au/review/ejournal/pdf/37-RA-2.pdf |date=June 17, 2009 }} [[John Maynard Keynes]], Richard Kahn, Richard Goodwin, [[Nicholas Kaldor]], Luigi Pasinetti, [[Joan Robinson]] and [[Piero Sraffa]] all started initially within the [[Neoclassical economics|mainstream Economics]] of their time. They all moved well and truly outside it, attempting to create either a revolutionary alternative or to rehabilitate the [[Marxist Socialism|classical Marxian tradition]], in most cases in the light of the [[Keynesians|Keynesian revolution]]. The one exception is Michał Kalecki, whose personal history and independent mind combined to place him virtually always outside the mainstream. Asimakopulos however viewed himself as a [[Neoclassical economics|mainstream]] economist. He even declined an invitation to be included in the first edition of Philip Arestis and Malcolm Sawyer's ''A Biographical Dictionary of Dissenting Economists'',Arestis, Philip and Sawyer, Malcolm. [https://books.google.com/books?id=Gi1-hW3cfo4C&dq=Biographical+Dictionary+of+Dissenting+Economists&pg=PP1&ots=V0PV3AwrbG&sig=43ctPBZ7iIauMjx7WexYRuMTMLE&prev=http://www.google.com.br/search%3Fq%3DBiographical%2BDictionary%2Bof%2BDissenting%2BEconomists%26ie%3Dutf-8%26oe%3Dutf-8%26aq%3Dt%26rls%3Dorg.mozilla:pt-BR:official%26client%3Dfirefox-a&sa=X&oi=print&ct=title#PPA9,M1 ''A Biographical Dictionary of Dissenting Economists'']. Edward Elgar Publishing, 2000, pp. 7–11. First published 1992. {{ISBN|1-85898-560-9}} because he regarded his views and contributions as belonging fully within the tradition of economics proper, not in a dissenting stream (he was included in the second edition).Harcourt, G. C. [http://www.cambridge.org/catalogue/catalogue.asp?isbn=9780511247613&ss=exc ''The Structure of Post-Keynesian Economics: The Core Contributions of the Pioneers'']. Jesus College, Cambridge Adobe eBook Reader. {{ISBN|9780511247613}} {{main|Keynesians}} ====Asimakopulos' critique of Keynes' ''Marginal Efficiency of Investment''==== In his ''General Theory'', John Maynard Keynes proposed an investment function of the sort < I = I0 + I(r) > where the relationship between investment and interest rate was of a rather naive form. Firms were presumed to "rank" various investment projects depending on their ''"[[internal rate of return]]"'' (or ''"marginal efficiency of investment"'') and thereafter, faced with a given rate of interest, chose those projects whose internal rate of return exceeded the rate of interest. With an infinite number of projects available, this amounted to arguing that firms would invest until their marginal efficiency of investment was equal to the rate of interest, i.e. < MEI = r >. Asimakopulos (1971, 1991), Piero Garegnani (1978) and several Post Keynesians offered a troublesome critique to Keynes' original formulation. Asimakopulos et al. questioned the very possibility of a downward-sloping ''Marginal Efficiency of Investment (MEI)'' function in the presence of unemployment. In particular, we can note that Keynes's multiplier story implies that if investment is undertaken then, by the multiplier, aggregate demand and output rises. But if the marginal efficiency of investment function is dependent on expected future returns, then should not the increased income and thus aggregate demand from the multiplier imply higher future returns? If so, then the MEI function ought to shift outwards to the right. This, in turn, implies that investment ought to increase which leads to another increase in aggregate demand and thus the ''MEI'' curve shifts out again, raising investment, etc.Asimakopulos et al., [http://cepa.newschool.edu/het/essays/capital/keynesreturn.htm ''J. M. Keynes's Internal Rate of Return''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090418015246/http://cepa.newschool.edu/het/essays/capital/keynesreturn.htm |date=April 18, 2009 }}, at HET website. As a result, it is easy to conceive that, in situations of unemployment where the multiplier works its magic, investment is actually indeterminate – or rather, an ever-shifting ''MEI'' curve could imply that all investment projects will be eventually undertaken and not merely those that are profitable at the given rate of interest since the profitability of projects is itself a function of aggregate demand and thus endogenous to the problem. ==Quotes on Asimakopulos== ::Tom Asimakopulos was a great Kaleckian scholar. His knowledge of the nuances and innuendos of Kalecki's approach to macroeconomics had no equal. {{small|Paul Davidson, Journal of Economic Issues.}} ::This book (''Keynes's General Theory and Accumulation'') is the legacy of a dedicated and tough-minded scholar who did his heroes the compliment of taking their work seriously, rather than just praising it. {{small|Robert W. Dimand, History of Political Economy.}} ==Major works published== {{refbegin|2}} Major works by '''Athanasios Asimakopulos''' (partial list): * ''Determination of Investment in Keynes's Model, The'', 1971, Canadian JE * [http://www.collectionscanada.ca/wbin/resanet/itemdisp/s=s/i=12906563/h=10/l=0/d=1/r=1/e=0 ''Economic Theory, Welfare, and the State: Essays in Honour of John C. Weldon'', McGill-Queen's University Press, 1991.] {{ISBN|0-7735-0853-8}} * ''Finance, Saving and Investment'', 1986, JPKE * ''Introduction to Economic Theory: Microeconomics, An'', Oxford University Press, 1978. {{ISBN|0-19-540281-2}} * ''Investment, Employment, and Income Distribution (Aspects of Political Economy)''. Westview Pr (Short Disc), 1988. {{ISBN|0-8133-0789-9}} * ''Kalecki and Keynes on Finance, Investment and Saving'', 1983, Cambridge JE * ''Kaleckian Theory of Income Distribution, A'', 1975, Canadian JE * [https://books.google.com/books?id=iCUGZire18IC&dq=athanasios+asimakopulos&printsec=frontcover&source=web&ots=yB8UZH-zNv&sig=QSoDXbobReK-r8MSqPXFsOQ6QDM#PPP1,M1 ''Keynes's General Theory and Accumulation'' (Modern Cambridge Economics Series) (Print on Demand). Cambridge University Press, 2004.] {{ISBN|0-521-36815-4}} * ''Keynes's Theory of Effective Demand Revisited'', 1982, Australian EP * ''Robinsonian Growth Model in One-Sector Notation, A'', 1969, Australian EP * ''Signification theorique de la Theorie generale de Keynes, La'', 1987, in Boismenu and Dostaler, La Theorie generale et le keynesianisme * ''Synoptic View of Some Simple Models of Growth, A'', with J.C. Weldon, 1965, Canadian JE and PS * ''Theories of Income Distribution'', Kluwer Academic Pub, 1988 {{ISBN|0-89838-232-7}} {{refend}} ==Bibliography== {{refbegin|2}} * [https://books.google.com/books?id=Gi1-hW3cfo4C&dq=Biographical+Dictionary+of+Dissenting+Economists&pg=PP1&ots=V0PV3AwrbG&sig=43ctPBZ7iIauMjx7WexYRuMTMLE&prev=http://www.google.com.br/search%3Fq%3DBiographical%2BDictionary%2Bof%2BDissenting%2BEconomists%26ie%3Dutf-8%26oe%3Dutf-8%26aq%3Dt%26rls%3Dorg.mozilla:pt-BR:official%26client%3Dfirefox-a&sa=X&oi=print&ct=title#PPA9,M1 Arestis, Philip and Sawyer, Malcolm. ''A Biographical Dictionary of Dissenting Economists''. Edward Elgar Publishing, 2000 pp. 7–11 {{small|First published 1992}}] {{ISBN|1-85898-560-9}} * Asimakopulos, Athanasios. Joan Robinson and economic theory. Banca Nazionale Del Lavoro Quarterly, v.151, pp. 381–409, December 1984. * [http://cje.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/reprint/9/4/405?maxtoshow=&HITS=10&hits=10&RESULTFORMAT=1&author1=Asimakopulos&andorexacttitle=and&andorexacttitleabs=and&andorexactfulltext=and&searchid=1&FIRSTINDEX=0&sortspec=relevance&resourcetype=HWCIT Asimakopulos, A. ''Finance, saving and investment in Keynes's economics: a comment''. Cambridge Journal of Economics, 1985; 9: 405–407.] * [http://cje.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/reprint/10/2/199?maxtoshow=&HITS=10&hits=10&RESULTFORMAT=1&author1=Asimakopulos&andorexacttitle=and&andorexacttitleabs=and&andorexactfulltext=and&searchid=1&FIRSTINDEX=0&sortspec=relevance&resourcetype=HWCIT Asimakopulos, A. ''Finance, investment and saving: a reply to Terzi''. Cambridge Journal of Economics, 1986; 10: 81–82.] * Asimakopulos, Athanasios. Introduction: Kalecki, Keynes and Joan Robinson. In Asimakopulos: ''Investment, employment and income distribution''. Aspects of Political Economy series. Boulder, Colo.: Westview Press; Cambridge: Polity Press in association with Blackwell, 1988, pp. 1–22 * Asimakopulos, Athanasios. Joan Robinson and economic theory. In. Investment, employment and income distribution. Aspects of Political Economy series. Boulder, Colo.: Westview Press; Cambridge: Polity Press in association with Blackwell, 1988, pp. 186–215 * Asimakopulos, Athanasios. Kalecki and Joan Robinson: An 'Outsider's Influence'. Journal of Post Keynesian Economics, v.11, pp. 261–78, Winter 1988–89. * Asimakopulos, Athanasios. Harrod and Robinson on the equilibrium rate of growth. Banca Nazionale del Lavoro Quarterly Review, n.170, pp. 345–58, September 1989. * Asimakopulos, Athanasios: Kalecki and Robinson. In: SEBASTIANI, Mario (ed.) Kalecki's relevance today. New York: St. Martin's Press, 1989, pp. 10–24. * Asimakopulos, Athanasios. Joan Robinson and the Americans. Journal of Post Keynesian Economics, v. 13, n.1, pp. 111–24, Autumn 1990. * Hein, Eckhard, Ochsen, Carsten. [http://www.blackwell-synergy.com/doi/abs/10.1111/1467-999X.00173?cookieSet=1&journalCode=meca ''Regimes of Interest Rates, Income Shares, Savings and Investment: A Kaleckian Model and Empirical Estimations for some Advanced OECD Economies''] Metroeconomica 54 (4), 2003, 404–433. * Cate, T., Colander, D., and Harcourt, G. Don D. Scott

[[Cedric the Entertainer]] | music = [[Terence Blanchard]] | cinematography = Tom Priestley Jr. | editing = John Carter | studio = State Street Pictures
[[Ice Cube|Cube Vision]]
[[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]] | distributor = [[MGM Distribution Co.]] | released = {{Film date|2002|09|13}} | runtime = 102 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = $12 million | gross = $77,063,924{{mojo title|barbershop|Barbershop}} }} '''''Barbershop''''' is a 2002 American [[comedy film]] [[film director|directed]] by [[Tim Story]],{{cite web|title=Barbershop (2002)|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0303714/combined|publisher=IMDb|accessdate=24 May 2012}} produced by State Street Pictures and released by [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]] on September 13, 2002. Starring [[Ice Cube]], [[Cedric the Entertainer]], and [[Anthony Anderson]], the movie revolves around social life in a [[barber]]shop on the [[South Side (Chicago)|South Side]] of [[Chicago]]. ''Barbershop'' also proved to be a star-making vehicle for acting newcomers [[Eve (rapper)|Eve]] and [[Michael Ealy]]. It is the first film in the [[Barbershop (film series)|''Barbershop'' film series]]. ==Plot== On a cold winter day, Calvin Palmer Jr. ([[Ice Cube]]) decides he has had enough of trying to keep open the [[barber]]shop his father handed down to him. He cannot borrow, revenues are falling, and he seems more interested in [[get-rich-quick scheme]]s to bring in easy money. Without telling his employees or the customers, he sells the barbershop to a greedy loan shark, Lester Wallace ([[Keith David]]), who secretly plans to turn it into a [[striptease|strip club]]. After spending a day at work, and realizing just how vital the barbershop is to the surrounding community, Calvin rethinks his decision and tries to get the shop back - only to find out Wallace wants double the $20,000 he paid Calvin to return it, and before 7 pm that day. Right after he admits to the employees that he sold the barber shop, and that it would be closing at the end of the day, the police arrive to arrest one of the barbers, Ricky ([[Michael Ealy]]). He is accused of driving his pickup truck into a nearby market to steal an [[Automated teller machine|ATM]], but it's revealed that Ricky's cousin J.D. ([[Anthony Anderson]]) committed the crime after borrowing Ricky's truck. As this would be Ricky's '[[Three strikes law|third strike]]', he could be sentenced to life in prison. Calvin uses the $20,000 from Lester to bail Ricky out of jail, but because J.D. set him up, Ricky is still angry. Calvin reveals that he found a gun in Ricky's locker in the barbershop and shows it to him. They stop the car and Ricky throws the gun into the river, proving that he does not want to get into any more trouble. Then they both go to confront Lester, as well as J.D. and Billy (Lahmard Tate), who took the ATM to Lester's place without his knowledge, still trying to pry it open. Calvin and Ricky demand that Lester give the barbershop back. Angered, Lester orders his bodyguard Monk to pull out his gun. The police arrive just in time to save Calvin and Ricky and arrest J.D. and Billy. Calvin and Ricky see the ATM, and get a $50,000 reward for returning it to police. They get the money, and the barbershop reopens with even better business than before. In the meantime, Calvin's wife Jennifer ([[Jazsmin Lewis]]) has given birth to a baby boy. ==Cast== * [[Ice Cube]] as Calvin Palmer Jr. * [[Anthony Anderson]] as J.D. * [[Cedric the Entertainer]] as Eddie Walker * [[Keith David]] as Lester Wallace * [[Michael Ealy]] as Ricky Nash * [[Sean Patrick Thomas]] as Jimmy James * [[Eve (rapper)|Eve]] as Terri Jones * [[Troy Garity]] as Isaac Rosenberg * Leonard Earl Howze as Dinka * [[Jazsmin Lewis]] as Jennifer Palmer * Lahmard Tate as Billy * [[Tom Wright (actor)|Tom Wright]] as Detective Williams * [[Jason Winston George]] as Kevin * [[DeRay Davis]] as Rayford * [[Parvesh Cheena]] as Samir * [[Carl Wright (actor)|Carl Wright]] as Checker Fred * Kevin Morrow as Monk * [[Norm Van Lier]] as Sam * [[Jalen Rose]] as Himself * Marcia Wright-Tillman as Angry woman who smashes car with bat ==Production== {{Unreferenced section|date=January 2015}} Produced on a $12 million budget, ''Barbershop'', with a story by Mark Brown and a screenplay by Brown, Marshall Todd, and Don D. Scott, was filmed in Chicago during the winter of 2001 to early 2002. The filmmakers used a storefront in the [[South Chicago, Chicago|South Chicago community area]] (79th Street and Exchange Avenue) that was once a [[laundromat]] to build the set for Calvin's barbershop, and the set was duplicated on a [[soundstage]]. Similar to what he achieved with his 1997 film ''[[Soul Food (film)|Soul Food]]'', producer [[George Tillman Jr.]] wanted to portray African Americans in a more positive and three-dimensional light than many other [[Hollywood, California|Hollywood]] films had in the past. This film also features three original songs by [[R&B]] singer/songwriter Sherod Lindsey. ==Reception== {{Expand section|date=November 2012}} The film received positive reviews. [[Rotten Tomatoes]] gives the film a "Certified Fresh" rating and a score of 82% based on 124 reviews,{{cite web|url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/barbershop/|title=Barbershop|date=13 September 2002|publisher=}} with the critical consensus "Besides bringing on the laughs, ''Barbershop'' displays a big heart and demonstrates the value of community." Metacritic gives the film a weighted average score of 66% based on reviews from 29 critics.{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/barbershop|title=Barbershop|work=Metacritic}} ==Sequels, spin-off and television series== {{Anchor|Sequels}} In 2004, MGM released the [[sequel]], ''[[Barbershop 2: Back in Business]]''. All of the original cast returned, but director [[Tim Story]] did not. This film was directed by [[Kevin Rodney Sullivan]]. In the same year, [[Billie Woodruff]] directed a [[Spin-off (media)|spin-off]] film entitled ''[[Beauty Shop]]'', with [[Queen Latifah]] as the lead (Latifah's character made her debut in ''Barbershop 2''). ''Beauty Shop'' was pushed back from a late summer 2004 release, and finally reached theaters in March 2005. During the fall of 2005, State Street and Ice Cube debuted ''[[Barbershop: The Series]]'' on the [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]] [[cable television|cable]] [[television network|network]], with [[Omar Gooding]] taking over [[Ice Cube]]'s role of Calvin. The character "Dinka" is renamed "Yinka" on ''Barbershop: The Series'', as "Dinka" is not a typical Nigerian name (although a certain tribe in the Nigerian middle belt bears the name "Dimka"). In addition, Isaac's last name is changed from "Rosenberg" to "Brice", and the character Ricky has been replaced by a more hardened ex-con, Romadal. In 2014, a third ''Barbershop'' film was announced, titled ''[[Barbershop: The Next Cut]]''. In late March of that year, MGM executives revealed that they have been negotiating deals with Ice Cube to appear in the film.{{cite web|url=http://www.deadline.com/2014/03/mgm-re-opens-barbershop-for-business-with-ice-cube-deal/|title='Barbershop' Sequel In Works With Ice Cube At MGM - Deadline|author=Mike Fleming Jr|work=Deadline}} A year later, MGM announced that the studio has been setting up deals with Cedric the Entertainer, Queen Latifah, [[Lisa Maffia]], and [[Nicki Minaj]] to appear in the film. [[Malcolm D. Lee]] directed the film and [[New Line Cinema]] distributed it.Fleming Jr., Mike (March 25, 2015). [http://deadline.com/2015/03/barbershop-3-new-line-ice-cube-mgm-1201398929/ New Line Joins MGM And Will Release ‘Barbershop 3.′] ''[[Deadline Hollywood]]'' The film was released on April 15, 2016.{{cite web|title=Barbershop: The Next Cut - ComingSoon.net|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/movie/barbershop-the-next-cut-2016|website=ComingSoon.net|accessdate=25 November 2015}} ==Soundtrack== {{Main|Barbershop (soundtrack)}} A soundtrack containing hip hop and R&B music was released on August 27, 2002 by [[Epic Records]]. It peaked at #29 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] and #9 on the [[Top R&B/Hip-Hop Albums]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Portalbar|African-American|Film in the United States|2000s}} * {{IMDb title|0303714|Barbershop}} * {{Amg movie|260400|Barbershop}} * {{Rotten-tomatoes|barbershop|Barbershop}} * {{mojo title|barbershop|Barbershop}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070929083101/http://www.moviehole.net/news/20020902_270.html Ice Cube interview for ''Barbershop''] {{Tim Story}} [[Category:2000s comedy films]] [[Category:American comedy films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:African-American films]] [[Category:Films set in Chicago]] [[Category:Films shot in Chicago]] [[Category:Films about race and ethnicity]] [[Category:Films directed by Tim Story]] [[Category:20th Century Fox films]] [[Category:Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer films]] [[Category:Cube Vision films]] [[Category:Films scored by Terence Blanchard]]

'''Bill Silva Entertainment''' is a concert promotion, artist management, touring, and publishing company based in [[Los Angeles]] and established in 1979.<ref name="celebrityaccess.com">[http://celebrityaccess.com/members/profile.html?id=538 "CelebrityAccess Industry Profiles"]. Retrieved on 25 February 2016.</ref><ref name="renmanmb.com">{{Cite web |url=http://www.renmanmb.com/live/guests/bill-silva |title=Archived copy |access-date=2016-02-25 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150129032832/http://www.renmanmb.com/live/guests/bill-silva |archive-date=2015-01-29 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>=http://digitalmediasummit.ca/wp-content/plugins/cmw-speakers/speaker_details.php?id=25</ref>
BSE has represented artists such as [[Jason Mraz]], [[blink-182]], [[Unwritten Law]], [[James Morrison (singer)|James Morrison]], and [[Christina Perri]], and has produced more than 10,000 shows.<ref name="renmanmb.com"/> Bill Silva, the company's founder, has won three Independent Promoter of the Year awards.<ref>Pollstar Creative Services [http://www.pollstarpro.com/PCIA-Static/welcome.htm "Pollstar Awards Archive"]. Retrieved on 25 February 2016.</ref>
The company is a partner in DT Model Management<ref name="emc|bowery">EMC|BOWERY. [http://www.prlog.org/12000086-international-agent-david-todd-opens-dt-model-management.html "International Agent David Todd Opens DT Model Management"]. Retrieved on 25 February 2016.</ref> and The Uprising Creative.
== History ==
=== Early Years: San Diego === While Bill Silva was a student at University of San Diego he started a concert promotion company for university parties. This led him to expand into the San Diego area and establish Bill Silva Presents in 1979. Over the next two decades the company brought acts such as [[The Who]], [[Simon & Garfunkel]], [[Devo]], [[The Police]], [[Pat Benatar]], [[INXS]], [[Diana Ross]], and [[Willie Nelson]] to the area.<ref name="celebrityaccess.com"/><ref name="renmanmb.com"/><ref name="digitalmediasummit.ca">http://digitalmediasummit.ca/wp-content/plugins/cmw-speakers/speaker_details.php?id=25</ref>
After securing a foothold in San Diego, Silva branched out into other parts of the southwest, promoting smaller shows in Arizona, Texas, Nevada, and Idaho. In 1982 he partnered with Feyline Productions and became the promoter for any of Feyline's shows outside of Colorado.<ref name="renmanmb.com"/>
In 1992 Silva teamed up with Andrew Hewitt to obtain exclusive rights to produce rock concerts at the [[Hollywood Bowl]].<ref>[http://articles.latimes.com/1992-08-23/news/mn-7298_1_hollywood-bowl "Hollywood Bowl Deal Questioned by Promoters"]. ''latimes''. Retrieved on 25 February 2016.</ref>
In 1993 Silva started representing the band [[Unwritten Law]]<ref>[http://www.allmusic.com/artist/bill-silva-mn0001881067 "Bill Silva"]. ''AllMusic''. Retrieved on 25 February 2016.</ref> after promoting one of their shows and BSE's management division, Bill Silva Management, was founded. Soon after, BSM added [[Blink-182]] to its artist roster.<ref name="renmanmb.com"/>
=== The Move To Los Angeles and the Start of the Jason Mraz Era ===
Bill Silva Entertainment moved from San Diego to Los Angeles in 1999.<ref name="celebrityaccess.com"/><ref name="renmanmb.com"/> He was introduced to [[Jason Mraz]], who he managed until 2017.<ref name="celebrityaccess.com"/><ref name="renmanmb.com"/><ref name="digitalmediasummit.ca"/><ref>https://www.sandiegoreader.com/news/2017/sep/12/blurt-jason-mraz-breaks-manager-bill-silva/</ref>
Silva also sold his concert division, Bill Silva Presents, to Universal Studios's concert division, which was later purchased by House of Blues Concerts. In March 2003 Andrew Hewitt and Silva left that venture, parting ways in concert promotion with the exception of their partnership at the Hollywood Bowl.<ref name="celebrityaccess.com"/><ref name="digitalmediasummit.ca"/>
Silva went on to re-establish Bill Silva Presents with a touring division that was kicked off by 2000's "Up In Smoke Tour" with [[Dr. Dre]], [[Snoop Dogg]], and [[Eminem]].<ref name="celebrityaccess.com"/><ref name="renmanmb.com"/><ref name="digitalmediasummit.ca"/> In 2005 Silva hired Eric Herz, a former executive at Avalon Attractions and Metropolitan Entertainment, to oversee Bill Silva Presents.<ref>[http://www.allaccess.com/net-news/archive/story/3501/herz-joins-bill-silva-presents "Herz Joins Bill Silva Presents"]. ''All Access''. Retrieved on 25 February 2016.</ref>
=== Recent Years: Expansion and Diversification === In 2011 Silva merged Bill Silva Presents with Live Nation Entertainment, placing Silva and Andrew Hewitt in charge of overseeing the company's concerts in the southwest region of the United States.<ref>George Varga (26 October 2011). [http://www.utsandiego.com/news/2011/Oct/26/live-nation-teams-bill-silva/ "Live Nation teams up with Bill Silva"]. ''The San Diego Union-Tribune''. Retrieved on 25 February 2016.</ref>
In 2012 the Bill Silva Entertainment team formed a partnership with the model manager David Todd to form DT Model Management.<ref name="emc|bowery"/>
== Bill Silva Management == Bill Silva Management has managed the careers of artists, comedians, and film directors since its founding in 1993.
The company began with San Diego bands Unwritten Law and blink-182, and managed [[Jason Mraz]] from 1999 to 2017.<ref name="celebrityaccess.com"/><ref name="renmanmb.com"/><ref name="digitalmediasummit.ca"/><ref name="theuprisingcreative">The Uprising Creative. [http://www.billsilvaentertainment.com/management/ "Bill Silva Entertainment"]. ''Bill Silva Entertainment''. Retrieved on 25 February 2016.</ref><ref>https://www.sandiegoreader.com/news/2017/sep/12/blurt-jason-mraz-breaks-manager-bill-silva/</ref>
Until 2008 Silva also managed and promoted tours for comedian [[Margaret Cho]].<ref name="celebrityaccess.com"/><ref name="digitalmediasummit.ca"/><ref>[http://legacy.utsandiego.com/news/features/20060521-9999-1a21varga.html "SignOnSanDiego.com > News > Features -- Hetfield and Silva honored at L.A. benefit concert"]. Retrieved on 25 February 2016.</ref>
In 2010 BSM client [[Christina Perri]]'s demo "Jar of Hearts" was featured on FOX's ''[[So You Think You Can Dance]],'' and was successful on the Billboard, iTunes, and Amazon charts.<ref>[http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/music/news/2010-07-10-christina-perri_N.htm?csp=34 "Christina Perri pries open the lid to fame with 'Jar of Hearts' - USATODAY.com"]. Retrieved on 25 February 2016.</ref>
The company currently represents [[Molly Kate Kestner]],<ref name="theuprisingcreative" /> [[Brooke Candy]],<ref name="theuprisingcreative" /> [[Dreezy]],<ref name="theuprisingcreative"/> [[Kittens (band)|Kittens]],<ref name="theuprisingcreative"/> [[XO-IQ]].<ref name="theuprisingcreative" />
== Silva Music Publishing == The publishing division of BSE began as a service for its management clients, primarily dealing with BSM artists and their collaborators.<ref name="celebrityaccess.com"/> In 2012 the company brought in Peter Coquillard, a music publisher who previously worked with Windswept Pacific, L.A. Reid, HITCO, and Network One Music Publishing, to expand the publishing division to include songwriters unaffiliated with BSM.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.songsummit.com.au/program/speakers-artists/peter-coquillard/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-02-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306221059/http://www.songsummit.com.au/program/speakers-artists/Peter-Coquillard/ |archivedate=2016-03-06 |df= }}</ref>
Silva Music Publishing consists of three publishing entities: Silva Tone Music (ASCAP),<ref>[https://www.ascap.com/Home/ace-title-search/index.aspx "ACE Title Search"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130306032310/https://www.ascap.com/Home/ace-title-search/index.aspx |date=March 6, 2013 }}. ''www.ascap.com''. Retrieved on 25 February 2016.</ref> BS Management Music (BMI),<ref>http://repertoire.bmi.com/publisher.asp?blnWriter=True&blnPublisher=True&blnArtist=True&keyID=861799&keyname=BS+MANAGEMENT+MUSIC&querytype=PubID{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> and Silva Lining Music (SESAC).<ref>[http://www.sesac.com/Repertory/PublisherSearch.aspx "Repertory Search :: SESAC"]. Retrieved on 25 February 2016.</ref>
Silva Tone consists of: * Ainslie Henderson, who wrote "Clockwatching" with Jason Mraz<ref>Ainslie Henderson. [http://www.musicaneo.com/sheetmusic/sm-121307_clockwatching_jason_mraz.html "Clockwatching (Jason Mraz)"]. Retrieved on 25 February 2016.</ref> * Michael Natter, who wrote "I Won't Give Up" with Jason Mraz * Stephen "Shebby" Ruchelman, who wrote for Hollywood Undead and Neon Trees including the track "Some Kind of Monster," which was featured on the ''Iron Man 3'' soundtrack.<ref>[http://www.halleonard.com/product/viewproduct.do?itemid=8203121 "I Won't Give Up, Pop Choral Series - Hal Leonard Online"]. Retrieved on 25 February 2016.</ref> * Tiffany Vartanyan, who has written with Ryan Tedder of One Republic and Demi Lovato<ref>[http://lybio.net/tag/tiffany-vartanyan/ "Tiffany Vartanyan"]. ''LYBIO.net Is A Movement For Internet Online Accuracy For Speeches, Text, Words, Quotes and Lyrics.''. Retrieved on 25 February 2016.</ref>
BS Management Music publishes for: * John Hogan of Unwritten law<ref>http://repertoire.bmi.com/title.asp?blnWriter=True&blnPublisher=True&blnArtist=True&keyID=5985274&ShowNbr=0&ShowSeqNbr=0&querytype=WorkID{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * John Anderson, who wrote and performed with Christine Perri<ref>http://repertoire.bmi.com/title.asp?blnWriter=True&blnPublisher=True&blnArtist=True&keyID=12574331&ShowNbr=0&ShowSeqNbr=0&querytype=WorkID{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * David Pack of Ambrosia<ref>http://repertoire.bmi.com/title.asp?blnWriter=True&blnPublisher=True&blnArtist=True&keyID=115945&ShowNbr=0&ShowSeqNbr=0&querytype=WorkID{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
Silva Lining Music currently publishes exclusively for Jeremy Thurber,<ref>[http://www.sesac.com/Repertory/SongSearch.aspx?songnum=785134 "Song Search :: SESAC"]. Retrieved on 25 February 2016.</ref> a pop artist who has collaborated with Jake Miller<ref name="allmusic.com">[http://www.allmusic.com/song/peace-out-mt0045191011 "Peace Out"]. ''AllMusic''. Retrieved on 25 February 2016.</ref> and Karl Wolf.<ref name="allmusic.com"/>

[[File:Bug Dome in Shenzhen by WEAK!.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Bug Dome at the Shenzhen & Hong Kong bi-city Biennale of Urbanism/Architecture in Shenzhen 2009.]] [[File:Bug Dome by WEAK! in Shenzhen.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Bug Dome covered by creepers surrounded by Shenzhen skyscrapers.]]
'''Bug Dome''' was a [[Bamboo#Construction|bamboo shelter]] created for the Shenzhen & Hong Kong bi-city Biennale of Urbanism/Architecture in Shenzhen 2009, China by a group of architects calling themselves WEAK!<ref>[http://www.dezeen.com/2009/12/14/bug-dome-by-weak/ Bug Dome by WEAK!] - Natasha Lyons '' Dezeen'' 2009</ref><ref>[http://www.archicentral.com/bug-dome-weak-for-szhk-biennale-2009-25682/ Bug Dome – WEAK! For SZHK Biennale 2009 | archiCentral<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140811065715/http://www.archicentral.com/bug-dome-weak-for-szhk-biennale-2009-25682/ |date=August 11, 2014 }}</ref>
The Bug Dome was inspired by the homes built by insects.<ref>[http://www.trendhunter.com/trends/bug-dome-by-weak Urban Bamboo Shelters - The Bug Dome by WEAK! Architects (GALLERY)<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://www.elcontexto.net/post/343370124/bug-dome-the-weak el conTEXTO | Bug Dome / the WEAK!<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> It was designed to be a sheltered area where underground band performances, poetry readings, and discussions could take place during the SZHK Biennale. After the Biennale, the shelter continued to be used as gathering place for illegal workers from the Chinese countryside, many of whom were living in nearby shelters and abandoned buildings.<ref>[http://www.archdaily.com/46710/bug-dome-the-weak/ Bug Dome / the WEAK!] - Cilento , Karen '' Arch Daily'' 2009</ref>
WEAK! was a collaboration of [[Hsieh Ying-chun|Hsieh Ying-Chun]], a Taiwan architectural activist specializing at collaborative construction and sustainable construction, Roan Ching-Yueh, an architect, curator and art critic, and Marco Casagrande, a Finnish architect, founder of C-lab.<ref>[http://www.designboom.com/architecture/weak-architects-at-shenzhen-hong-kong-biennale/ weak architect at shenzhen] - '' Designboom'' 2009</ref> The WEAK! architects create their projects by recomposing existing materials with minimal effort to total impact. The 'bug dome' was constructed out of bamboo and weak concrete in the form of cement mixed with soil.<ref>[http://designhotpot.com/chinese-architects-rediscovering-the-tradition-of-bamboo/ Chinese architects rediscovering the tradition of bamboo - Design Hotpot<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
All the necessary materials were collected from around the building site and will return to the natural environment when the Dome is no longer needed.<ref>[http://www.metrohippie.com/bug-dome-in-shenzhen/ Bug Dome in Shenzhen | Metro Hippie<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
